dc.dc:description: This Arabic lectionary is the earliest dated Christian manuscript in Arabic and its colophon (shown) dates it to 859.
Current location: Monastery of St. Catherine, Sinai, Egypt.
dc.dcadesc:subject: Manuscripts, Arabic--Egypt.
Lectionaries--Egypt.
Illumination of books and manuscripts, Early Christian--Egypt.
Colophons of manuscripts.
dc.dc:title: Arabic Lectionary.

dc.dc:description: The church of the Red Monastery (Dayr Anba Bishay) is a basilica with a long nave, terminating in an elaborate tri-lobed sanctuary. Each of the three half circles that form the trefoil sanctuary consists of two ornamented tiers topped by a semi-dome. Depictions of Christ, the Virgin Mary, apostles, evangelists, prophets, and angels create a complex series of messages about salvation. The addition of monastic saints connects the paintings to the setting of the monastery. The numerous and brightly colored designs on the architectural sculpture are the best surviving example of what were Classical and Egyptian traditions that continued into Late Antiquity.
dc.dcadesc:subject: Coptic church buildings--Egypt.
Coptic art--Egypt.
Architecture, Byzantine--Egypt.
Apostles in art.
Church decoration and ornament.
dc.dc:title: Interior Semidomes in Red Monastery Church.

dc.dc:description: This carving has an uncommonly high degree of three-dimensionality, most pronounced in the central figures. It is likely that the object was intended to function as an applique, but whether to decorate a piece of furniture or an interior architectural space is open to question. The central figure is believed to possibly be St. Mark, surrounded by his 35 successor Coptic patriarchs of Alexandria.
Current location: Musée du Louvre, Paris, France.
dc.dcadesc:subject: Art, Byzantine--Egypt.
Bone carving--Egypt.
Appliqué.
Saints in art.
Patriarchs and patriarchate.
dc.dc:title: Tusk Fragment with Apostle on Throne, Surrounded by Followers in Front of a City.

dc.dc:description: This mosaic pavement is from the Church of the Virgin in Mataba, Jordan. The inscription in the central medallion refers to the icons of the Virgin kept in the church.
dc.dcadesc:subject: Mosaics, Byzantine--Jordan.
Art, Sassanid--Jordan.
Pavements, Mosaic--Jordan.
Church buildings--Jordan.
Art, Umayyad--Jordan.
Decoration and ornament, Abbasid.
dc.dc:title: Mosaic Pavement in the Church of the Virgin in Madaba, Jordan.

dc.dc:description: These well-wrought liturgical objects—chalices, censers, a strainer, and a representation of the dove of the Holy Spirit—were among the possessions of a Christian church in the affluent merchant town of Attarouthi in Syria, then one of the richest lands of the Byzantine Empire. The chalices, censers, and strainer were used for the Divine Liturgy, or Eucharist service, in which Christians take consecrated wine and bread in commemoration of the Last Supper and Christ's death. In the early seventh century, Syria fell first to the Sasanian Persians and then to the armies of Islam. These works were probably buried in haste in a protective container at some moment when the Byzantine army was retreating from attacks on the region.
Current location: Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, New York.
dc.dcadesc:subject: Silverwork, Sassanid--Syria.
Silverware--Syria.
Censers--Syria.
Chalices--Syria.
dc.dc:title: The Attarouthi Treasure.

dc.dc:description: This mosaic pavement was laid in the main church in the large ecclesiastical complex of Saint Stephen at Umm al-Rasas.
dc.dcadesc:subject: Mosaics, Byzantine--Jordan--Umm al-Raṣāṣ.
Art, Sassanid--Jordan--Umm al-Raṣāṣ.
Pavements, Mosaic--Jordan--Umm al-Raṣāṣ.
Church buildings--Jordan--Umm al-Raṣāṣ.
dc.dc:title: Mosaic Pavement in the Church of Saint Stephen at Umm al-Rasas, Jordan.

dc.dc:description: This type of ewer, derived ultimately from a Roman-Byzantine shape, does not appear in Sasanian silverware before the 6th century. The lavish decoration consists of four female figures in a dancing pose dressed in diaphanous clothing, each holding two objects. They stand in arches formed of rosettes that are supported by pilasters decorated with spiraling vine.
Current location: Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, United States.
Medium: Silver, embossed, punched, repousse, chased, gilded.
Measurements: H. 34.2 cm, Max. diameter 13.3 cm.
dc.dcadesc:subject: Silverwork, Sassanid--Iran.
Silverware--Iran.
Ewers--Iran.
Women in art.
dc.dc:title: Ewer with Dancing Female Figures within Arcades.

dc.dc:description: Remnants of a border with plain disks on a dark background can still be seen on the upper part of the larger fragment. Below, four figures remain, and their apparel is of special interest.
Current location: Benaki Museum, Athens, Greece.
Medium: Embroidery in polychrome wool on plain-weave ground of undyed linen.
dc.dcadesc:subject: Textile fabrics, Byzantine.
Textile fabrics, Sassanid.
dc.dc:title: Fragments of a Wall Hanging with Figures in Persian Dress.

dc.dc:description: The excavations of the palace of emperor Khusrau I (r. 531-79) and surrounding residences of the site of Sasanian capitol Ctesiphon (in present-day Iraq) brought to light a large number of architectural stuccoes. These examples demonstrate the ornamental form and new technique of the time using cast gypsum.
Current location: Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, United States.
Measurements: 44.5 cm wide (frame elements) and 64.8 cm wide (tiles)
dc.dcadesc:subject: Art, Sassanid--Iraq.
Decoration and ornament, Architectural--Iraq.
dc.dc:title: Elements of a Frame and Tile Panel.

dc.dc:description: The Naples Dioscurides (MS Suppl. gr. 28) is an illuminated early 7th-century Greek herbal. The book has 172 folios and the style of Greek script used in the manuscript indicates that it was probably written in Byzantine-ruled southern Italy, where ancient Greek cultural traditions remained strong.
Date created: late 6th century - early 7th century.
Current location: Biblioteca Nazionale, Naples, Italy.
Medium: Ink and pigment on parchment.
dc.dcadesc:subject: Manuscripts, Byzantine--Italy.
Illumination of books and manuscripts, Byzantine--Italy.
Herbals--Early works to 1800.
Medicinal plants in art.
dc.dc:title: The Naples Dioscorides (fols. 50r and 33v).

dc.dc:description: The Naples Dioscurides (MS Suppl. gr. 28) is an illuminated early 7th-century Greek herbal. The book has 172 folios and the style of Greek script used in the manuscript indicates that it was probably written in Byzantine-ruled southern Italy, where ancient Greek cultural traditions remained strong.
Date created: late 6th century - early 7th century.
Current location: Biblioteca Nazionale, Naples, Italy.

dc.dcadesc:subject: Manuscripts, Byzantine--Italy.

Herbals--Early works to 1800.
Medicinal plants in art.
dc.dc:title: The Naples Dioscorides (fols. 25v - 26r).

dc.dc:description: This oval bowl is a fine example of the kind of silverware that entered the Sasanian repertoire in the early 6th century. One of the common motifs decorating a drinking bowl is the inhabited vine, as seen here.
Current location: Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, United States.
Medium: Silver, mercury gilding, hammered, repousse, chased, gilded.
dc.dcadesc:subject: Silverwork, Sassanid--Iran.
Silverware--Iran.
Bowls (Tableware)--Iran.
dc.dc:title: Bowl with Inhabited Vine Scroll.

dc.dc:description: On the handle, Neptune stands with his characteristic trident atop a fish. Fishermen with tridents and harpoons, fishnets surrounded by fish, shells, and a swimming bird adorn the exterior of the ladle.
Current location: State Heritage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia.
Medium: Silver, gilded, chased and incised.
dc.dcadesc:subject: Art, Byzantine--Turkey--Istanbul.
Decorative arts--Turkey--Istanbul.
Silverware--Turkey--Istanbul.
Ladles (Utensils)--Turkey--Istanbul.
dc.dc:title: Ladle with Neptune and Fishing Scenes.

dc.dc:description: Throughout the Byzantine Empire, bone plaques were used to decorate furniture, small boxes, and pyxides. Images like these could have been used alone or together in more extensive compositions. Most of the numerous surviving examples having been preserved by the dry climate of Egypt.
Current location: Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, United States.
Measurements: 13.6 x 5.3 x 1.5 cm and 10.7 x 4.5 x 1.9 cm.
dc.dcadesc:subject: Art, Byzantine--Egypt.
Bone carving--Egypt.
Men in art.
Male nude in art.
dc.dc:title: Dionysos and Silenus.

dc.dc:description: The body of the flask is decorated on its broad sides with medallions showing Nereids seated on sea creatures and on its narrow sides with fish, water birds, and shells.
Current location: State Heritage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia.
dc.dcadesc:subject: Art, Byzantine--Turkey--Istanbul.
Decorative arts--Turkey--Istanbul.
Silverware--Turkey--Istanbul.
Bottles--Turkey--Istanbul.
Nereids (Greek mythology)
dc.dc:title: Flask with Nereids.

dc.dc:description: The relief scene on this plate depicts two companions of Dionysos: a dancing Silenus carrying a wineskin on his shoulders and a maenad holding percussive musical instruments.
Current location: State Heritage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia.
Medium: Silver, gilded, chased and incised.
dc.dcadesc:subject: Art, Byzantine--Turkey--Istanbul.
Decorative arts--Turkey--Istanbul.
Silverware--Turkey--Istanbul.
Bacchantes.
Dance in art.
dc.dc:title: Plate with Silenus and a Maenad.

dc.dc:description: The hero Meleager is shown here as he prepares to join Atalanta on the Calydonian Boar Hunt. Depicted in relief, this epic story was one of the most common themes in Classical art.
Current location: State Heritage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia.
dc.dcadesc:subject: Art, Byzantine--Turkey--Istanbul.
Decorative arts--Turkey--Istanbul.
Silverware--Turkey--Istanbul.
Meleager (Greek mythology)
Atalanta (Greek mythology)
Hunters in art.
Hungtin dogs in art.
dc.dc:title: Plate with Meleager and Atalanta.

dc.dc:description: Originally sewn onto the bottom of a tunic, this band depicts scenes from the life of the biblical king, David.
Current location: State Heritage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia.
Medium: Polychrome wool and undyed linen.
dc.dcadesc:subject: Textile fabrics, Byzantine--Egypt.
Coptic art--Egypt.
Clothing and dress--Egypt.
dc.dc:title: Textile Fragment with Episodes from the Life of David.

dc.dc:description: This wall hanging features a central medallion and four outer squares whose borders are filled with various creatures. In the middle of the medallion and squares ride five pairs of Amazons. The iconography is a pastiche of motifs typically found throughout Byzantine and Islamic worlds.
Current location: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, United States.
Measurements: H. 104 3/4 in. (266 cm), W. 62 5/8 in. (159 cm), Wt. 183 lb. (83kg)
dc.dcadesc:subject: Wall hangings--Egypt.
Textile fabrics, Byzantine--Egypt.
Islamic textile fabrics--Egypt.
Coptic art.
Amazons in art.
dc.dc:title: Hanging with Images of Abundance.

dc.dc:description: This fragment of a mosaic pavement shows a villa in a garden, from the northern section of the peristyle courtyard of the Great Palace in Constantinople.
Current location: Istanbul Mosaic Museum, Turkey.

Helios (Greek deity)

dc.dc:description: This leaf appears at the end of the Septuagint version of the book of Job. The images have also been noted as being modeled on the contemporary Byzantine emperor Heraclius.
Location created: White Monastery, Sohag, Upper Egypt.
Current location: Biblioteca Nazionale, Naples, Italy.
dc.dcadesc:persname: Heraclius, Emperor of the East, approximately 575-641--Art.

Illumination of books and manuscripts, Byzantine--Egypt.
Bible. Job.
